title: What's the difference between s & 's at the end of a word? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are multiple ways to use the apostrophe( ' ). There are two distinct uses, which the OP seems to be confused about. 1. To show possession. For a singular noun, add an apostrophe followed by the letter s.Eg.This is Abhijith's question.That is Juliet's shrine. If the noun ends with an s, a single apostrophe, with no s following it. (Some writers add an s after the apostrophe. This is not very common, though.)Eg.The class' responsibility.Mr. Jones' calculator.Mr. Jones's calendar. (rare) If the noun is a plural and the plural form ends with the letter s, a single apostrophe is added at the end.Eg.Guys' night out.Girl's night out. (Incorrect. It implies only one girl)Girls' night out.A childrens' park. (Incorrect. Childrens is not a word!)A children's park. (Plural. Not ending with s. Add apostrophe and s.) 2. For contractions. Apostrophes are added where letters are removed.Eg. can't [ can not ]won't [will not ]I've [ I have] The confusion occurs when words like has, is, was are contracted. They are contracted to just the letter s. He's [He is / He was / He has] .. DOES NOT mean, belonging to him. Further confusion occurs when we use proper nouns. The meaning of the 's depends on the context. Let me illustrate. Abhijith's the one who asked this question.[ Abhijith is the one ... ] The 's here expands to is (or was), and does not mean belonging to.  This is Abhijith's question.The 's here means 'belonging to Abhijith'. Extra tip:Don't use 's to form plurals.Chip's doesn't mean many chips.Upvote's doesn't mean multiple upvotes. Further reading:A very common mistake that people make is between its and it's. The grammar nazis on the Internet do not spare anybody that makes this mistake (guilty!). You could read an excellent answer by User here Meenakshi Nandhini's answer to What's the difference between "its", "it's" and "its'"? Can anyone explain with proper examples?

In addition to the explanations already provided, here are some tips: ILLUSTRATING POSSESSION: the apostrophe and ‘s are both a substitute for “of”the books of Abhijith = Abhijith’s booksthe bikes of the boys = the boys’ bikesan acquaintance of John = John’s acquaintanceWRONG because redundant though accepted = an acquaintance of John’sBUT, can’t be avoided in: a friend of mine and that attitude of hisTIP FOR SINGULAR POSSESSIVE: write singular noun first: child, boy, houseadd ‘s to make it possessive: child’s toy, boy’s bike, house’s colorTIP FOR PLURAL POSSESSIVE: write the noun as plural first: children, boys, houses, carsthen do what is needed to make it possessiveadd ‘s — children’sor add only ‘ if the “s” is already there — boys’, houses’ , cars’make sure the possessed item is also plural — children’s toys, boys’ bikes, houses’ driveways, cars’ owners or cars’ owner [many cars owned by one person]if the combination is hard to say, as houses’ driveways, write it the long way as driveways of all the houses or my preference, the driveway of each house.EXCEPTION: when the sound of a second “s” is part of the pronunciation, then a second “s” is added.Example: decorating taste of the Prince and Princess of Wales = the Wales’s [say Waleses] decorating tasteAlways write the singular or plural form of the word first. Then add the ‘s or just the apostrophe to make it possessive. Mistakes usually arise when trying to make a word possessive before first deciding whether it needs to be singular or plural.
